86. One can also depict Cities and Countries,
as Parrhasius did for them (?)
who painted with learned hand
the image of Athens, there such understanding
of bold representations appeared in it
that one saw there the manners
of the Athenians, their Customs of all types,
the essence of their morals, and ordinary affairs.

87. Rome, the World’s Capital, is, for her valor,
depicted as the helmeted Pallas,
sitting with weapons on a pile of armor
and other things fitting for battle,
in her right hand with a Pike or Lance,
and in front, a small figure of Victory, with a wreath
of Laurel, and a palm frond
in her left hand, according to noble custom.

88. Attentive students, you have followed me
through many steps to learn how to arrange Histories,
to depict various things with their characteristics.
Now we will descend these steps
and step over the next part.
When I have time and, after refreshment, the desire,
we shall at another time and in another place
continue this great Subject more broadly.

ab.b:
The Depiction of the Affections, passions, desires and sufferings of Men.
The Sixth Chapter.

div.ab:
1. No one is so steadfast that he can
fully master his emotions and frailties,
for the Emotions and passions within––
moving him and touching his heart and senses–
the visible body generates
and reveals through noticeable signs
in gestures, deeds, or actions,
as comprehensible signs in the body.
left-middleNo one is free of passions, Emotions, or the tendency toward human frailty

2. The study of nature lets us hear
distinctly the names of things,
called Emotions, first and foremost
love, lust, fear, pain and wrath,
grief and sorrow, which assail the heart,
faintheartedness and fear, difficult to retrain,
Also conceit, and fierce hatred:
left-middleWhat human Emotions or passions are.
